texts.en:
39-year-old Zam has been operating her soft drinks business for the past 20 years in Lugazi. The happily married mother of 1 says she began this business with savings from her farm sales business. 20 years have been years of nothing but hard work, sacrifice, determination and perseverance. Without that perseverance she says she would not have achieved that longevity. She says the huge market for soft drinks in her area of operation keeps her business going. Most of her drinks sell highly during the dry seasons, and demand normally subsides during the rainy seasons.

Travelers along the route that leads one from Kampala, Uganda's capital city, to the east side of the country are normally the ones who buy a treat of her drinks. This route has many traveler refreshment stopovers, notably in the area where Zam operates.  On the side, Zam also does farming and cattle raising.

She says her gross monthly sales profit totals up to 250,000 Ugandan shillings (~$97), and she says with this Kiva loan she intends to purchase more soft drinks, like sodas and passion fruit juice, to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more soft drinks, like sodas and passion fruit juice, to resell.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.es:
1.	Teresa es una señora de 51 años que vive con su esposo e hijos en un pequeño pueblo en Guanacaste llamado la Garita. La Garita es una planicie de clima bastante cálido donde se desarrollan actividades tales como la ganadería, Agricultura y el Turismo Rural.

Desde hace varios años Teresa se dedica a la gastronomía, ya que tiene a cargo la cocina de una escuela privada, los vecinos de su comunidad se muestran muy satisfechos por el servicio brindado. Dice que tener el apoyo y la ayuda de su esposo le facilita seguir con el proyecto. Además dice que el proyecto le es muy interesante ya que ha visto como poco a poco su negocio crece y la demanda cada vez es más fuerte.

Actualmente Doña Teresa está solicitando un micro crédito de ¢500.000 (quinientos mil colones) para la compra de repuestos de automóvil, para arreglar el medio de transporte que le facilita su trabajo. Con esto ella espera hacer crecer más su negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida. Su negocio va bien pero por falta de dinero no ha podido hacerlo crecer más. 

Doña Teresa es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal La Garita una de las 110 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer crédito, y espera poder seguir participando de manera más activa en este tipo de organizaciones.
texts.en:
Teresa is a 51 year old woman who lives with her husband and children in a small town in Guanacaste called la Garita. La Garita ia on a plain that is very hot. People work in cattle, farming and tourism there. 

For several years, Teresa has made food. She is in charge of the kitchen of a small private school. The residents of his community are very satisfied with the service she has offered. She says that she has the support of her husband, who helps her continue with the project. She also says that the project is very interesting, since she has seen her business grow little by little and the demand get stronger.  

At present, Teresa is asking for a micro loan of ¢500.000 (five hundred thousand colones) to buy replacement parts for her car, to fix her transportation for work. With this, she hopes to grow her business more and improve her quality of life. Her business is going well but due to lack of money, she hasn't been able to make it grow more.  

Teresa is a member of the Empresa de Crédito Comunal La Garita, one of the 110 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan, and she hopes to keep participating in a more active way in this type of organization.

loans.use: buy replacement part for her transportation for work.

loans.name: Ndegbomie Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the “Ndegbomie” group from Kenema, a city in eastern Sierra Leone. They are local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org, to apply for a loan of 500,000 SLL for each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Satta is the leader of this group. The 35-year-old is married to a driver and they have two children attending primary school. Satta has been doing business for many years now; she sells fish. With her share of this loan, she will buy a large quantity of fish.

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of fish.

loans.name: Narcisse

texts.fr:
Client de 47 ans, marie et père de 8 enfants dont l'age varie entre 5 et 20 ans dont tous vont a l’école.Il y'a de cela 20 ans ,  a la faillite  et fermeture de l’unité de production ou il travaillait, vu la charge de ses enfants il se lance dans la vente des grillades dans un grand carrefour non loin du plus grand marche de la ville.
Ayant profite du peu d'argent qu'on lui avait paye, il acheta une barbecue et quelque cartons de cuisses de poulets, avec la forte demande de ses clients, le prêt lui permettra de renforcer le stocks de ses marchandises, tel que 5 cartons de cuisses de poulets, 5 cartons de gésiers et 2 cartons de poulets doux, ses ventes sont considérables, il a en moyenne 50.000 frs a 110.000 frs par jour.
Sa stratégie est de vendre tous les jours de 6h a minuit , très dynamique , il réalise des épargnes et avec ses bénéfices il assure la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Narcisse is 47 years old, married and the father of 8 children aged between 5 and 20, all of whom go to school. Twenty years ago, in order to be able support his family when the production unit where he worked went bankrupt and had to close down, Narcisse started selling grilled meat at a large crossroads near the biggest market in town. He used the small amount of money he had been paid to buy a barbecue and some boxes of chicken thighs. The resulting customer demand was high and, thanks to his considerable sales, he now makes on average between 50 000 and 110 000 francs a day.
An active and enterprising man, he sells his wares every day from 6 o´clock to midnight. He manages to make some savings and uses his profits to pay for his children´s education.
He will use this loan to restock on goods including 5 boxes of chicken thighs, 5 boxes of gizzards and 2 boxes of Doux chicken.

loans.use: to buy boxes of chicken thighs, boxes of Doux chicken and boxes of gizzards.

loans.name: Regie

texts.en:
Regie is a farmer in the Philippines, and is married to a housekeeper and a loving woman. Regie is engaged in the  hog raising  business and his earnings from it go to his children's  education. Recently, Regie has encountered financial shortages in being able to finance his family and business needs.  Hence, he is asking for a loan of P30,000 to buy feed and vaccines for his hogs. He believes that the loan will help him survive the financial crisis he has encountered. 

Regie has no bigger dream in life than for his children to complete their education and become professionals someday.

loans.use: to buy feed and vaccines for his hogs.

loans.name: Rene

texts.en:
Rene is a 45-year-old married man with 3 children. His oldest child is 19 years old.

Rene is a farmer from Sto. Niño, South Cotabato. He has been growing rice for 12 years now. Rene earns about 15000 PHP per month doing this type of farming. He works hard to improve his business. Rene has requested this loan to purchase fertilizers and insecticides.

In the future, Rene hopes to have a stable business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and insecticides

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en: Vincent needs another loan to buy a motorcycle. He has been into brick making for 13 years and now he wants to venture into the transport sector to increase his income.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is 21 years old, married, and has five children, all of whom are in school. She has a business of selling soap and cooking oil in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.

Joyce requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to help her purchase more goods for sale. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase soap, rice, sugar, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Wilber Enrique

texts.es:
Wilber tiene 29 años de edad, soltero, vive con una hermana y dos sobrinos. Sus padres se separaron cuando él era muy pequeño, por lo que siempre ha vivido con sus hermanos.

Desde hace tres años, Wilber se ha dedicado a la venta de especias: comino, achote, pimienta gorda, pimienta negra  y otras más. Su hermana fue quien le enseño esta actividad, la cual se ha convertido en su fuente de ingresos. Él se levanta a las 5:00 de la mañana, a realizar sus labores diarias. Se traslada a la capital del país a comprar las especies, para esto aborda un autobús, el viaje dura dos horas y media, para llegar a la Terminal, luego aborda un microbús que lo conduce al centro de la ciudad, después camina a pie hasta  el mercado central, es ahí donde compra su mercadería y regresa a casa. Las especias las compra por libras y por galones. Por lo que, debe dividir en bolsas pequeñas las porciones, para posteriormente irlas a vender a los diferentes municipios y cantones, él va de tienda en tienda, ofreciendo su mercadería, para regresar a su casa a las 5:00 de la tarde.

Wilber utilizara su préstamo, para comprar: 12 libras de achote, 12 libras de comino, 14 libras de pimientas, 12 libras de comino molido, 10 libras de sal de ajo, 8 libras de sal de cebolla, 10 libras de canela, 6 libras de romero, 9 libras de chan, 6 libras de almidón, 8 libras de bicarbonato, 4 libras de anís, 6 galones de mostaza, 6 galones de salsa negra, 6 de dulce, 6 galones de chile, entre otros más.

Con esta inversión, Wilber surtirá su negocio, comprara por mayor y esto le permitirá dar mejores precio a sus clientes y cubrirá la demanda de estos. Obtendrá mejores ingresos ahorrorando tiempo y dinero, ya que él viaja dos veces por semana a la capital y con la inversión solo ira una vez a la semana a comprar su mercadería.

Wilber es un joven emprendedor, que le ha tocado luchar para salir adelante. De los ingresos que reciba por la venta de su mercadería, él ahorra, ya que quiere que su negocio crezca y emplear a dos o tres personas, para que salgan a vender y él encargarse de preparar la mercadería. De esta forma tendrá más tiempo disponible, ya que por razones económicas dejo de estudiar en la universidad, y su gran sueño es graduarse de licenciado en ingles, pues solo le hacen falta dos años. Para alcanzar sus sueños, Wilber trabaja muy fuerte y ahorrara lo más que pueda, para continuar con sus estudios el próximo año y graduarse.
texts.en:
Wilber is 29 and single. He lives with a sister and two cousins. His parents separated when he was very young, so he has always lived with his siblings.

Wilber has sold spices for three years: cumin, annatto, allspice, black pepper, and others. His sister taught him this business, and it is now his source of income. He gets up at 5:00 am to go to work. He goes to the capital city by bus to buy his spices. The trip takes him two and a half hours to get to the terminal, then he gets on a microbus which drives him downtown. After this, he walks to the central market where he buys his merchandise; then he returns home. He buys the spices by the pound and by the gallon. He then divides them into smaller portions to sell in the various municipalities and cantons. He goes from store to store, offering his products, and comes home at 5:00 pm.

Wilber will use this loan to buy: to buy 12 pounds of annatto, 12 pounds of cumin, 14 pounds of peppers,
12 pounds of ground cumin, 10 pounds of garlic salt, 8 pounds of onion salt, 10 pounds of cinnamon, 6 pounds of rosemary, 9 pounds of chia, 6 pounds of starch, 8 pounds of bicarbonate, 4 pounds of aniseed, 6 gallons of mustard, 6 gallons of black salsa, 6 of jam, 6 gallons of chili, and other items.

With this investment, Wilber will be able to stock his business. He will buy his products wholesale, allowing him to offer his customers better prices and to cover their demand. He will be able to make a better income through saving time and money, since he goes to the capital twice a week, and with this investment he will only have to go once a week.

Wilber is an enterprising young man, who has fought to get ahead. He saves his earnings, since he wants his business to grow so that he can hire two or three people to go out and sell his products while he stays back and prepares them. This way he will have more time; for financial reasons, he had to stop attending university. His greatest dream is to graduate with a Bachelor in English; he is only two years short. In order to achieve his dreams, Wilber works very hard and saves as much as he can so that he can continue with his studies next year and graduate.

loans.use:
to buy 12 pounds of annatto, 12 pounds of cumin, 14 pounds of peppers,
12 pounds of ground cumin, 10 pounds of garlic salt, 8 pounds of onion salt, 10 pounds of cinnamon, 6 pounds of rosemary, 9 pounds of chia, 6 pounds of starch, 8 pounds of bicarbonate, 4 pounds of aniseed, 6 gallons of mustard, 6 gallons of black salsa, 6 of jam, 6 gallons of chili, and other items.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy food products

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 15 years.  She is 38 years old, married to Ndungu and they have four school-going children.  

She was introduced to KADET LTD by one of our existing clients and this will be her first loan.  She plans to use the loan amount to buy farm supplies. In the future, Mary hopes to improve her farming skills and make more profit, thereby improving the living standards of her family.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Kudbudin

texts.ru: Кудбудин занимается скотоводством. Он проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 47 лет. Он женат. У него шестеро детей. Он берет кредит для закупа коровы.
texts.en: Kudbudin raises cattle for a living. He lives in Kulob. Kudbudin is 47 years old, married and has six children. He is taking out this loan to purchase an additional cow.

loans.use: to purchase a cow

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose is 26 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is single. 

Jose has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & beverages. He has had this business for one year. He requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Jose has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Jose hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Easther Christy

texts.en:
Easther Christy is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 

Easther Christy has had a food shop or "sari-sari" store for 4 years. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell.

Easther Christy is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks, and beverages to sell.

loans.name: Seham

texts.en:
Seham is a 39-year-old married woman who has four family members. She is from Al Karak, Jordan.

She is requesting a loan of 500 JOD to pay for various products such as perfumes, makeup, and clothes to sell. In the future, she would like to increase her products through opening a shop.

Seham prefers not to display her photo on the Internet. Thus, the above photo is of her husband.

loans.use: to pay for various products such as perfumes, makeup, and clothes to sell.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Salamatu.  She is a widow and has four children who are 5, 10, 13 and 21 years old. She has one additional dependent who lives with her helping with the house chores. In 1999, Salamatu established her cooking utensils and cutlery business. She began this business just to be self-reliant after dropping out of school. Her business is located at the city center and her main customers are adults. Working 7 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about Le 927,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan of Le 3,000,000. Salamatu has already received and successfully repaid two loans and now requires a new loan in order to buy glass plates, spoons, food flasks and teacups. She hopes that this loan will help her to increase her stock and expand the business. In the future, Salamatu plans to educate her children. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy glass plates, spoons, food flasks and teacups

loans.name: Aurora Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hà is 48 years old and she is married.
 
She has worked in agriculture raising pigs for more than 10 years.
Hà lives in Tinh Gia district, a  rural town in Thanh Hoa province.
Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region. 
The main hardship that Hà faces is lack of capital.  She is requesting a loan to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in future..
This is Hà first loan with Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.
With her business profit, Hà hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase baby pigs to raise and sell in future.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en: Honesty Mini-supermarket, owned by Madam Catherine O., is visited by quite a number of people in her vicinity. She needs capital to re-stock her shop to meet the demands of her numerous customers. She is therefore seeking a loan of $850.00 from Kiva to help her expand. Madam Catherine is very hardworking and honest and can pay back the loan.

loans.use: re-stocking capital for her mini-supermarket

loans.name: Julio

texts.en:
Julio has lived on his lands for about 40 years. He has 6 children, all of whom are grown. Some of his sons still work with him on the farm during the heavy cycles of rice production. He has depended on his lands for his entire life. He also has some cattle that he raises and uses for milk production. Julio will invest the loan mainly in pesticides and the rental of machinery to pick the rice he has already planted. The loan will help increase his profits as he will not lose as much production as before and it will be easier to collect his product.

The Santa Lucia Communal Bank

Julio is part of the newest Communal Banks in the recently developed Mifex Rural Finance Program. All of the members of the Centro Agricola de Santa Lucia Communal Bank are part of an Association of Rice Farmers in Santa Lucia. Their association works cooperatively to help in the commercialization of the product after it has grown. They will use the micro-loans to prepare their lands and cultivate rice on their farms. Because they form part of a communal bank, they are all each others guarantors for the loan. This means that if for some reason one person in the group cannot fully repay the loan, the other borrowers and the Primero de Agosto Association are responsible for the amount in default. The members of the bank also participate in a program designed to teach and encourage savings among the group. Promoting savings is often forgotten in many micro-finance programs, but Mifex believes that is imperative for the communities we work with to have capital reserved for future investments or unexpected difficulties.

Below is more information about Santa Lucia compiled by Luis Crespo and Robert Edgar of the Mifex team when evaluating the potential of the sector for the Rural Finance Program. Special thanks to Mario Balazantegui who provided expert insight and contributed to the development of the alliances with the local organizations.

Economy of Santa Lucia

Santa Lucia County has a population of about 33,000 people. The sector is fit for rice cultivating because it is not in the lowlands and therefore it is not at risk of flooding. There is also great access to water because of the Daule River, which is accessible to many of the farmers in the area. About 70% of the farmers have basic infrastructure for watering their crops.

Rice production is the main economic activity of the area as about 80% of the people are rice farmers. Almost everyone is either directly or indirectly involved with rice production, as they produce, commercialize or participate in activities that add value to the product. Within the county, there is a small town also named Santa Lucia. The town is filled with many small businesses and it serves as the social and commercial hub of the area.

Rice Farming in Santa Lucia

Most of the people in the Santa Lucia area are small farmers. They produce about 100 sacks of rice per hectare of land. In order to farm they first must prepare the lands by removing weeds and plowing. The farmers then fill an area with water to form what is known as a paddy field, because rice is a very water-intensive crop. The rice seeds are either dispersed freely (the process is known as boleo in Spanish) or hand sowed. Once the rice has grown, most farmers rent machinery that helps them gather their production. A risk factor does exist in rice farming because of drought, but in Santa Lucia this is somewhat mitigated by the access to water form the nearby river.

Access to Credit

The biggest struggle in the area has been the lack of credit. Because people do not count on formal financial services, they have turned to loan sharks for financing. They have been affected by expensive lines of credit that exceed 100% interest a year and can be as expensive as 240%. Intermediaries also exploit the farmers because of their outstanding debt. Farmers also lack skills and knowledge to commercialize their products and pay fair prices for their crops.

Loan Use

The loans in this sector will be used to to buy soil, seeds, fertilizer and insecticides. They will also be used to prepare the land prior to farming, to plant the seeds and purchase other materials. The loan repayment schedule is also different from the typical micro-entrepreneur. Because farmers see the profits from their investments 5 or 6 months after making their initial expenditures, Mifex asks them only to pay 50% of the capital in the first 6 months of the loan. The rest of the debt must be paid in the seventh and final month.

loans.use: Rice farming

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa has a small beauty salon where she styles hair and provides manicures. She started this activity about two years ago after quitting her job as a domestic assistant. With $150 she saved from her job she set up a salon in her home.

Rosa started off in the business just cutting men and women’s hair. She slowly evolved into styling hair and providing manicures. As a complimentary source of income she sells different cosmetics and other items from her store. She is hoping that this loan will allow her to invest in these types of products that are popular with her clients.

Rosa is 33 years old and has two children. Both of her children are in school and se hopes she can help provide them with a good education.

loans.use: Invest in cosmetics and other items she can sell from her salon

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her food and charcoal sales  business

loans.name: Tomás

texts.es:
Tomás is 57 years old, a shoemaker, and married to Gladys Godoy, who is 48 years old. They have two sons; one who is 27 years old and one who is 24 years old. They are professionals now thanks to the work of their parents. Tomás has two nephews who are working with him, to whom he is teaching the trade and paying so they may contribute to their family expenses.

Tomás learned the trade from his uncle, who he worked with when he was very young, and after ten years he was able to own his own shoe business in his home. With the loan he plans to buy leather, soles, thread, and glue to make shoes in bulk, since he has received a lot of orders from his clients.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

Tomás tiene 57 años, zapatero de profesión, casado con Gladys Godoy de 48 años de edad. Tienen dos hijos uno de 27 años y otro de 24 años, profesionales gracias al trabajo de sus padres. Tiene dos sobrinos que están trabajando con él, a quienes les enseña el oficio y les remunera para contribuir con los gastos de su familia. Tomás aprendió el oficio de su tío con quien estuvo trabajando desde muy joven y después de 10 años habilitó su propia zapatería en su domicilio. Proyecta con el crédito comprar cuero, plantillas, hilos, pegamentos para realizar trabajos en gran cantidad, ya que ha recibido bastante pedidos de sus clientes.

loans.use: Purchase leather, soles, threads, and glue.

loans.name: Mutia

texts.en: Mrs. Mutia A. is 35 years old, married and has 3 children; she lives in Mushi, Lagos State of Nigeria. She sells baby items and has been in this business since 1987. She has been a LAPO member for the past 4 years. She needs the loan of $400 to buy more baby items for sale.

loans.use: To buy more baby items for sale

loans.name: Luaono

texts.en: Luaono is the president of Moamoa k Uta Center. She has been running her shop for more than three years now and this is the first time she is borrowing money for the business. Luaono's shop is located at the front of her house. It is open from six o’clock in the morning till nine in the evening. The shop is actually owned by her daughter but when the daughter moved to New Zealand, Luaono took over. She keeps her shop open six days a week and she can manage to earn about $340 WST (US$ 136) a day. Luaono is still active and she is doing well at running her business.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Erisa A (Iv) Group

texts.en:
Safina is 25 years old and married with four children. She sells raw foodstuffs from a stall in the local market. Aidah sells charcoal. Sylvia, Jesca and Aisha deal in second-hand clothes. All five women have applied for a loan to expand their businesses. Safina wants to use the extra income generated by the loan to pay school fees for her children.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy additional items to sell to their customers

loans.name: Aziz

texts.en:
Aziz was born in 1965. He is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fizuli region. Aziz had settled in Fizuli region in the Kayidish village, an area which is built specifically for IDPs.

He is married, with three children. Ten years ago, he started this business in agriculture and dairy. Now, he needs a loan of $1200 to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Njuk

texts.en: Mrs. Njuk M., 39, owns a plot of farmland with her husband and they grow vegetables. They make on average $8 a day of income. This couple has four children and all of them are students. They make a good profit from planting vegetables. To increase growing they are requesting a loan from Kiva to purchase petroleum, fertilizers and seed (vegetables). (Husband is pictured because Mrs. Njuk M. is not available)

loans.use: To purchase petroleum, fertilizers and seed (vegetables).

loans.name: Chantal

texts.fr:
Born around 1976 in Adjohoun, in Africa's second richest valley situated in the south-east of Benin near its political capital, Mrs Chantal D. is married and the mother of three children. Mrs D. has been living in Avotrou, a shantytown in Cotonou, for over five years and sells sewing materials. She has worked in the sector for six years and has a great deal of experience. She is currently faced with an influx of customers whom she cannot satisfy. She is therefore requesting this loan in order to replenish her stock so that she can fulfill the expectations of her customers and in particular gain their loyalty.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.

Née dans les années 1976 à ADJOHOUN dans la deuxième vallée la plus riche de l’AFRIQUE et située au sud-est du BENIN près de la capitale politique du BENIN, dame D. Chantal est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Installée à AVOTROU dans un bidonville de COTONOU depuis plus de 5 ans, dame D. Chantal est une revendeuse des produits de mercerie. Opérant depuis 6 ans dans ce secteur, elle est dotée d’une grande expérience. Actuellement elle est confrontée à une affluence des clients qui ne trouvent pas satisfaction. Elle sollicite alors ce crédit pour s’approvisionner afin de répondre aux attentes de sa clientèle et surtout gagner sa confiance.

loans.use: To buy 100 meters of lining, 10 boxes of sewing thread and other sewing materials.

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua A. is a fifty-six-year-old divorced mother of three children. She has been very supportive of her children since she became a single parent.

Akua has sold used clothes at her local market for the past fifteen years. Because of this, she will be able to pay for her two children to finish school. With low capital, she is not able to buy larger quantities of used clothes to sell. She would like to use the loan to buy more bales of used clothes that come with variety to increase her stock. She hopes to raise enough income to support her two children to finish school.

She belongs to the community called Christ Nti Trust Group. In this group, members act as social collateral for each to guarantee access to loans. They also help each other to repay the loans through positive peer pressure.

loans.use: To buy larger bale quantities of used clothes to sell.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama K. is forty five years old. She is a widow and the mother of two children. Through hard work, Ama has supported one of her children to finish senior high school and the other is currently in school. She is a food vendor and sells kenkey as well as maize. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to  increase her income to support her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Mercy Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loan and utilize peer pressure to repay the loan

loans.use: To buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem C., 47, is a farmer and her husband is tuk-tuk taxi driver. (The tuk-tuk is a type of motorized 3-wheeled vehicle.) The couple lives in Khsom Village, Kandal Province, Cambodia. Mrs. C. earns about $2 per day and her husband earns $3.50 per day. They have seven children, one of whom is married. Her two sons who work as bricklayers in Phnom Penh also help with the family’s expenses.

Because of her desire to expand her husband’s business, Mrs. C. is asking for a loan so her husband can purchase a new trailer for his tuk-tuk. The new trailer will allow him to attract more customers and thereby increase his earnings as a tuk-tuk driver.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a new trailer for her husband's tuk-tuk

loans.name: Juany Del Pilar

texts.es:
Juany spent her time as a homemaker, but two years ago her husband had an accident and is still disabled. She found herself looking for a business that would help her to meet expenses, since his pension alone was not adequate. Thus she decided to open her small shop, which she has stocked little by little and has successfully increased her sales.

She needs a loan of US $250, which she will repay in 3 months, in order to buy more merchandise. With your help, she will make her business grow.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva volunteer

Juany se dedicaba a las labores del hogar, pero hace 2 años su marido tuvo un accidente y quedo discapacitado, fue entonces que se vio en la necesidad de buscar un negocio que le ayudara a cubrir los gastos familiares, ya q con la pensión de su esposo no les alcanzaba. Fue así como decidió poner su pequeña tienda, la cual poco a poco ha ido surtiendo y ha logrado incrementar sus ventas.

Ella necesita un préstamo por US $250 que pagara en 3 meses para comprar más mercancía. Con tu ayuda ella hará crecer su negocio.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Mame Bousso

texts.fr: Mame Bousso est née le 17 juillet 1971 à Kaolack.elle est mariée et s'active dans le commerce de crintin (cloture) et des denrées alimentaires depuis quatre ans.
texts.en:
Mame Bousso was born on July 17, 1971 in Kaolack. She is married and has been in the business of bamboo fences and general food items for four years.

Translated from French by Lucia Franzese, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sale of general food items and fences

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 40 year old Moshi K. from Dar es Salaam She is married with three children, between the ages of 16 and 25. She is also responsible for supporting two dependents because their parents do not take care of them.

Moshi has been selling flour since 2002. She buys flour at wholesale prices and retails it in smaller amounts for a profit. Her business is doing well. She works at the business for twelve hours per day, seven days per week, and is assisted by one employee. Moshi currently earns about $100 from her business. She is requesting a loan of $500 in order to purchase more flour for her business. In the future, she plans to expands her business. Moshi thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of microleasing is that is allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase flour in bulk.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.en:
"La Amistad" is a large group of men and women receiving loans. This particular loan is going to 15 of the group members. This group is a great example of the success that microcredit can bring. The members of this group are looking for their seventh or eighth loans, and all have had a taste of success. Each member started out with virtually nothing, but now each has a small business and great hope for the future. Inocencia is the group representative, and she has a small clothing business. She is an extremely hardworking mother of four children, and is really excited about the way her business is going. She feels like she can proviD. for her family, and that is a feeling she has never had before. She dreams of all her children attending universities, and she is on her way to fulfilling that dream. This whole group is all moving up in life, and want to continue expanding and growing their businesses. Everyone is excited about the future and what it will bring for this hardworking group.

On behalf of Inocencia, the group, and Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: To support a clothing business

loans.name: Koem Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Koem Heng C. is 49 years old and lives in Ou Sngoeun village in Takeo Province. She is a farmer who earns income growing rice and different types of vegetables. She is requesting a loan to buy six piglets and pig food. Adding pig breeding to her farming will increase her income and improve her living conditions. She is the mother of two children who are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and pig food to start a pig-breeding business

loans.name: Ruziboy

texts.en:
Born in 1952, Ruziboy T. is married and the father of six children. He is an agriculturist, a job he loves, and it has been the principle source of income for him for the last 32 years. He has 0.8 hectares of land where he produces different kinds of vegetables, and also he has a area of apricot trees on his land. Thanks to the experience that he has gained during the 32 years, he gets a rich harvest every year from his land. In light of the current high demand, Ruziboy would like to improve his land and production to meet the market. In order to do this, he is seeking a loan to buy fuels and lubricants, fertilizer, and saplings for improving and expanding his harvest. He would then be able to better provide for his children's schooling, health, and food. You could become an important part of Ruziboy's family's life. He deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving him.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is perhaps best known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road; the end of Alexander the Great's rule; and for its famous great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets such as Rudaki, Ibn Sina (Avicenna), Firdousi, Omar Haiyam, Jomi, Mavlavi Rumi and many others. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New Western culture and Central Asian traditions. 
But, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. 

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fuels and lubricants, mineral fertilizers, and saplings.

loans.name: Julia Carlota

texts.es:
Julia es social del Bancomunal 24 de 0ctubre
Julia es casada, tiene 46 años y  tres hijos, los de 22, 21 y 16 años; los mayores están casados y el ultimo  estudia ingles. 

Ella cuando era joven estudio  para auxiliar de niños, llego a trabajar en un colegio por varios años hasta que se caso, y se dedico a criar a sus hijos, empezó a vender ropa en consignación pero el taller de donde sacaba  la ropa cerro y dejo de vender ropa. 
actualmente Julia  esta sola en Lima por que su esposo se fue a trabaja en el extranjero desde hace 6 meses, animada por una amiga, entra a la venta de productos de belleza por catalogo,
Desde que comenzó en Finca  ha aprendido a como vender su producto y como sacar el capital y no gastárselo, y sacar la ganancia, también aprende de las experiencias de las  socias  en el Bancomunal 
Necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para compra productos  de belleza por catalogo en oferta, y poder estoquearse. 
El sueño  de Julia es tener una librería bazar.
texts.en:
Julia is a member of "Bancomunal 24th of October". She is 46 years old, and married with three children, ages 22, 21 and 16 years. The older children are married, and the youngest studies English. When she was young, Julia studied to help children, and worked in a school for several years until she got married, at which point she focused on raising her children. Julia started selling clothes on consignment, but the shop where she got the clothes from closed down and stopped selling clothes. Julia is currently alone in Lima, as her husband went to work abroad for 6 months. Encouraged by a friend, Julia began selling beauty products by catalog. Since she began at Finca, Julia has learned how to sell her product, how to save her capital instead of spending it, and has also learned from the experiences of other members of Bancomunal. Julia needs a loan of 800 Peruvian Soles to buy beauty products offered by catalog, and stock up. Julia's dream is to have a book bazaar.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Lucas, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beauty supplies for her sales inventory.

loans.name: Flor Consuelo

texts.es:
La señora Flor Consuelo Y. D. T. tiene 74 años, vive en la Urb. Santo Dominguito, distrito D. Trujillo, provincia D. Trujillo, departamento D. La Libertad, Perú.
Ella estudio hasta 4to D. primaria, dejó los estudios para que sus hermanos pequeños puedan estudiar y se dedicó a trabajar. Tiene 05 hijos y ninguno depenD. económicamente D. ella.
Flor se dedica a la venta D. leña y briqueta, al comienzo vendía menú y sus clientes la incentivaron para que venda briqueta y leña, empezó vendiendo leña y briqueta en poca cantidad en un mercado, con el tiempo se hizo conocida y D. muchos clientes, ahora su negocio es granD. y muy rentable. Su negocio lo desarrolla en su propio domicilio.
Con el primer crédito D. 300 soles que recibió D. su Banco Comunal “Mujeres  del Milenium”, lo invirtió en la compra D. briquetas.
Con este crédito D. 3000 soles, que será cancelado en 4 meses, lo invertirá en la compra D. leña y briqueta.
Flor sueña con comprarse un carro.
texts.en:
Flor Consuelo Y. D. T. is 74 years old. She lives in the town of Santo Dominguito, in the Trujillo district of Trujillo province in La Libertad, Peru. She attended school until fourth graD., then dropped out and began to work so that her younger siblings could go to school. She has five children, who are all financially independent. Flor sells firewood and charcoal. She started out selling pre-cooked meals, but her customers requested that she sell charcoal and firewood. She began to sell firewood and charcoal in small quantities in a market, and over time she became well-known and gained many clients. Now her business is large and very profitable. She runs her business out of her home. With her first loan of 300 soles that she received from the Communal Bank "Women of the Millennium," she invested in the purchase of charcoal. With this loan of 3000 soles, which she will repay in four months, she will invest in the purchase of firewood and charcoal. Flor dreams of buying herself a car.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase firewood and charcoal for her business

loans.name: El Buen Futuro 5 Group

texts.en:
Group 5 from the El Buen Futuro ("The Good Future") Bank of Hope is starting their 6th loan cycle with Esperanza International. They all agree that the loans they've been taking have been a great help to them to keep their businesses in good shape, and make sure that they always have merchandise available for their clients. These entrepreneurs have been able to successfully repay five loans and hope to use this next one in their business expansion projects. 

Antonia S. is the group representative. She has four children who are grown. The youngest is 18 years old. However, she still supports all her children with their education, which is something she describes as one of her biggest challenges. She's glad that she is able to help them build a better future for themselves through a good education. In the future, she would like to have a house of her own and her own clothing store. 

Antonia and her group mates are working hard on their businesses, but they still need the all support that we can give. On behalf of Esperanza International and this group of entrepreneurs, thank you for your support!

loans.use: To buy new clothes for resale

loans.name: Fafilat

texts.en: Fafilat is 40 years old and married with five children. She sells cooked foods and lives in Walebadejo Street, Igbo-elerin, Lagos State in Nigeria. Fafilat needs the loan amount of N50,000 to buy more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Hoang Thi

texts.en:
Tùng Hoàng (1402081652) is a 28-year-old female living in the town of Thanh Hoá.  She is married and has two infant-aged children.  To making a living, Tùng owns & operates a business venture in the manufacturing sector operating a manufacturing business.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from manufacturing & selling generally manufactured products to local businesses and community members.  Tùng has been engaged in this business for over five years and earns approximately 2000000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, Tùng joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Tùng has successfully repaid a previous loan from TYM Fund.  This previous loan was used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.  Tùng is now requesting a new loan of 9000000 VND, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products.  The loan will be the second loan taken out by the borrower from TYM Fund.  Tùng plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make mats

loans.name: Sister United Group

texts.en:
This is Bondu M., Monica KaM., Amie L., Konba S. and Jeninatu KaM.. They named their group Sisters United.  They are all local entrepreneurs in Waterloo, twenty miles from Freetown. This is the first loan they are requesting from SMT/Kiva. They would like a loan to enable each of them to further develop their businesses, make better sales and higher profits, and consequently improve on their living standards.

Bondu M. (left) is the leader of the group. She is thirty-two years old. She was born in Kono, in Eastern Sierra Leone. Her husband is a police officer and they have four children in primary schools and a baby. Bondu has been a businesswoman for over nine years now.
 
Bondu sells provisions – milk, sugar, butter, bread, mayonnaise, sardines etc. in a kiosk outside of her house. At the corner, she also sells market foods like rice, salt, onions, margarine and so on. She will invest this loan into her business by adding a more extensive variety of items to those she now sells.

loans.use: To buy a larger variety of goods to sell.

loans.name: Alma Lucia

texts.es: Alma Lucia C. M. tiene la edad de 53 años, su estado civil es casada. Doña Lucia tiene 2 hijos. La actividad económica de es un taller de carpintería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Doña Alma inicio este negocio por su familia ya que anteriormente el negocio estaba a cargo de su Papa y fue el quien le enseño este negocio y como necesitaba un medio de supervivencia decide hacerse a cargo del negocio. El propósito de Alma es mantener activo este negocio y además es lo único que les podría dejar a sus hijos. El financiamiento es destinado para capital de trabajo por lo que su inversión será destinada para la compra de materia prima como madera, pintura, brocha, pega, lija entre otros. Los sueños de Doña Alma es seguir trabajando con Fundación León 2000 ya que es por medio de esta que recibe la ayuda de las organizaciones amigas.
texts.en:
Alma Lucia C. M. is 53 years old and married. She has 2 children, and has had a carpentry shop for 5 years. Alma began this business because of her family as the business was originally run by her father and it was he who taught her this business. As she needed a way of earning a living she decided to take over the business. Alma plans to continue this business and she plans to leave it to her children. The financing will be used for working capital to invest in buying materials such as wood, paint, paintbrushes, glue, sandpaper and more. Alma dreams of continuing to work with the Fundación León 2000 because it is through this organization she receives help fellow women entrepreneur organizations.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Oyuntogtoh

texts.en:
Oyuntogtoh O. lives with her husband and three children in Arhangai province, one of Mongolia's central provinces. Her two sons are students in a local high school and her husband looks after his one-year-old infant daughter at home.

Oyuntogtoh has a small business in clothes-making. She started her business in 2006 using her old sewing machine at home. She mostly sews various women’s clothes by request of her customers. Since the start in 2006, her business has done well and her business capital has increased from 100,000 MNT to 500,000 MNT (100,000 MNT is approximately $70).

As for the expansion, she now rents a work place for her business. In the future, she hopes to have her own work place, instead of paying high rent. She requests a loan to purchase raw materials such as various cottons for her business.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials such as various cottons for her business

loans.name: Kihara Mothers 2 Immaculate Mercy Group

texts.en: I. Mercy is 20 years old, married with two children. She has been in business for two years so far, selling coffee as a cash crop. She is using this loan to purchase bags of coffee to add to her stock. This will improve her business, adding capital and allowing her to sell wholesale. I. Mercy is a hardworking business lady encouraging people in her community to work. Her dream is to construct a residential house.

loans.use: To purchase bags of coffee

loans.name: Muslima

texts.ru: Гуломова Муслима проживает в районе Хамадони. Возраст 45 лет. Вдова, имеет 2 детей. Муслима более 5 лет занимается бизнесом. Она имеет торговую точку на рынке, где торгует одеждой. Она просит кредит, дял увеличения товараоборота. Т.к. увеличится товараоборота, прибыль тоже увеличиться, а это ей очень нужно.
texts.en:
Muslima G. lives in the Hamadoni region. She is 45 years old. She is a widow and has two children. Muslima has been doing business for more than five years. She has a vendor spot on the market where she sells clothing. She is asking for a loan to increase her inventory. This way when the sales increase her profit will increase too which she needs a lot.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase commodity circulation

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en:
Veronica J. sells onions and other spices at Beposo near Shama. Veronica has received junior high school education. She is married and has three children. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Veronica has been selling onions since 2004. She is responsible for buying food for the family. Her loan will be used to support the business by buying more food supplies for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to expand her business.

loans.use: to support the business by buying more food supplies for resale

loans.name: Nuevo Amanecer Ii Group

texts.es:
Florencia M. tiene 57 años y tiene el negocio de venta de regalos, ella compra vajillas, vasos, camas, peluches y otros y los adorna con papel de regalo en un embase sólido (cartón) y los vende cerca de locales, además tiene su puesto de venta en San Pedro. Ella se animó a ingresar al grupo “Nuevo Amanecer II” por invitación de unas vecinas y porque necesita del préstamo para comprar mercadería.

Roxana, Alicia, Carlota, Margarita y el resto de los integrantes de este grupo también tienen sus negocios como la venta de verduras, víveres, galletas, otras tejen prendas, pero todas necesitan el crédito para mejorar su negocio comprando mercadería y materia prima.
texts.en:
Florencia Madani, 57, sells gifts. She buys dishes, glasses, stuffed animals, and others. She puts them in cardboard containers and decorates them with gift paper. She sells them in nearby locations. She also has a sale’s location in San Pedro. She was motivated to join the Nuevo Amanecer II group by an invitation from a neighbor. She needs the loan to buy merchandise. Roxana, Alicia, Carlota, Margarita, and the rest of the group members also have businesses like selling vegetables, supplies, and crackers. Others knit clothes. They all need a loan to improve their business by purchasing merchandise and raw material.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise and raw material

loans.name: Salina Chebet

texts.en:
Salina Chebet is 36 years old and married to a farmer. She is blessed with three little children. Her cereal business is located in Moiben. She supplies the cereals to institutions, which are her major customers.

She has been in this cereal business for the past three years. With the loan she is taking from KADET she plans to add more stock which includes beans. In future she intends to grow her business and be able to purchase more cereals so that she can supply it to many other institutions.

Salina Chebet S. was introduced to KADET by a previous borrower.

 ABOUT KADET LTD. 

Kadet Ltd is a microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya that was formed in 2000 to offer access to financial services to the rural communities through the microfinance model. Kadet is the only microfinance in Kenya with a strong rural presence and a genuine concern for the welfare of children and the communities we serve. As a member of the Association of Microfinance Institutions in Kenya, Kadet has continued to empower communities by providing access to easy-to-pay loans. Loan products available at the MFI are designed to offer solutions to challenges facing communities in these rural habitations. Obtain more information on Kadet from the press section of the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To add more stock to her cereal shop which includes beans.

loans.name: Angela Del Carmen

texts.es: Ángela del Carmen F. L. tiene la actividad de mercadería en general. Ella tiene 32 años, es una mujer muy alegre y disfruta mucho de su trabajo, Ángela tiene mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación León 2000, por lo que siempre los financiamientos han sido de gran ayuda. A pesar de los problemas que ha obtenido como es su salud. Actualmente ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra ropa para damas, cosméticos, calzado y otras prendas de vestir. Su deseo es seguir trabajando para tener los ingresos necesarios para salir adelante con su familia.
texts.en:
Ángela del Carmen F. L. sells general merchandise. She is a very happy 32 year old woman, and she greatly enjoys her work. Angela has worked with the Fundación León 2000 for a long time. In spite of the health problems she has had, the loans have always been a big help. She is currently asking for a loan for working capital to buy women’s clothes, cosmetics, footwear, and other articles of clothing. Her wish is to keep working to have the income she needs to get ahead with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Augmenter sa surface cultivable et acheter des engrais

loans.name: Charles Otieno

texts.en:
Charles is married to Beatrice, and they have five children: Marion (17 years old), Millan (14 years old), Talash (10 years old), Tracy (5 years old), and Angela (1 and a half years old).

Charles has been in the tailoring business for fourteen years. He was introduced to KADET by existing groups, and he has no previous credit history. His area of business is in a stall within the market, and the market is situated in a highly populated area. Charles wants a loan to buy a stock of materials in readiness for the Christmas holiday season and festivities.

With the extra profits, Charles plans to buy an overlock sewing machine, which he hopes will help him with his tailoring business. He describes himself as hardworking.

About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke.

loans.use: To buy a stock of materials in readiness for the Christmas holiday season and festivities

loans.name: Jonard

texts.en:
Jonard M. is from the village of D'ban, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. He is 35 years old and married and with a baby. To make a living, Jonard owns and operates a motorcycle transport business, providing transportation in the local community. Jonard has been in business for over ten years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Jonard joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jonard has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase tires and accessories . Jonard is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP, which also will be used to purchase tires and accessories. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Jonard from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to meet his family's daily needs. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and accessories

loans.name: Ann Gichugu

texts.en:
Ann is a 56-year-old widow with six children between the ages of 19 and 33. Ann runs a primary school in the Kitengela area of Kenya. She has been in the business for one year now, and she makes a profit of about 17,000 Kenya shillings a month. 

She has never borrowed from an MFI; this will be her first loan from KADET. She will use the loan to buy school textbooks and more seats. She hopes to expand the school to enroll more children.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve the living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy textbooks and seats for the school

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy products for his cafeteria

loans.name: Kristine

texts.en:
Kristine L. is 32 years old. She manages a small sari sari (general store) business which gives her the opportunity to sell a variety of goods and to earn income for her family. She is still single and she supports her siblings and nieces. The income she makes in her sari sari store not only helps her in terms of providing for her needs but also for the needs of her parents and siblings. 

She would like to apply for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise so she can offer her customers a wider variety of selections.

loans.use: To buy additional merchandise for her sari sari (general store) business.

loans.name: Mrs. Sao Ly Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Sao Ly T. is 28 years old and she is the village bank president. This village bank loan consists of fifteen members who will each use the loan for a different purpose. They all live in Snuol Khpos village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Sao Ly T. is a silk weaver and her husband, Mr. Pan Nea Buon, is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which he grows rice. He is also a laborer who is able to make a small income to support the family living.

This family now faces a problem because Mrs. Sao Ly T. has insufficient money to buy silk. Thus, she decided to request a loan to buy silk for weaving to increase her income. This couple has two children who are studying at the local public school.

loans.use: To buy more silk

loans.name: Jenny Elizabeth

texts.es:
Jenny N. de 29 años, vive en una zona periurbana ubicada en la Perimetral de Guayaquil, su casa es de cemento cuenta con todos los servicios básicos, esta separada pero tiene 2 hijos estudiantes de escuelas fiscales. 

Jenny comenzó vendiendo comida en la ventana de su casa fue poco a poco teniendo ingresos suficientes para poder convertir el puesto de comidas en un bazar. 

Jenny ahora trabaja todos los días desde las 08h00 hasta las 21h00 de la noche, vendiendo cuadernos, plumas, fomix etc. Una de las dificultades que tiene es la falta de iluminación que hay en las calles de su casa.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar una vitrina, cuadernos, plumas, hojas para agrandar el negocio. En el futuro quiere poner una sucursal y también adecuar su casa para que ya no venda la papelería por la ventana.
texts.en:
Jenny N., 29, lives in a periurban area along Guayaquil's beltway in a cement house that has all basic utilities. She is separated and has two children enrolled in public school. Jenny began selling prepared meals from a window in her house and bit by bit earned enough to make her food stall into a store. Now, Jenny works from 8am until 9pm selling notebooks, pens, styrofoam, etc. One of the difficulties she faces is the lack of street lighting in her area. She will use the funds to buy a display case, notebooks, pens, sheets of paper to enlarge her stock. In the future, she wants to open a branch of her store and also set up her house so that she doesn't have to sell her paper goods through her window anymore.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Display case, notebooks, sheets of paper.

loans.name: Youness

texts.en: Youness has been the owner of a shoe store in his town since 2000. He’s 46 years old, married and has three unemployed children. His shop is situated in a busy area so, over the years, he has had a growing number of clients pass by his shop and buy shoes. He's always trying to fill his shop with the latest collections to attract more clients. Today, Youness is asking to borrow $1,000 to add new decor and renovate his shop in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: To add new decor and renovate his shop

loans.name: Sarmila

texts.en:
Mrs. Sarmila P. lives in Bhakapati. To improve her standard of living, she opened a grocery shop five years ago where she sells different items, such as noodles, rice, and biscuits (cookies).

The demand for grocery goods is increasing in her area, so Mrs. P. is requesting her first loan from Kiva. She seeks a loan to buy grocery goods to meet the demand. She is very grateful for your support. She will use her income to provide a better education for her children.

Mrs. P. lives with her husband and three children. She has one son and two daughters. Her older daughter is studying in university and her younger daughter is studying in grade 11. Her son is studying in grade 8.

loans.use: To buy more groceries for her store

loans.name: Pacita

texts.en:
Mrs. Pacita G., from the village of Upper Bunawan, Calamba Misamis Occidental, is 58 years old, married and blessed with four adult-aged children. She owns and operates a business venture selling a variety of grocery items in the local community. Engaged in her business for more than five years, she earns a monthly net income of 3,000.00.

In 2001, Pacita joined PMPC to access its programs and services. She is now requesting her 14th loan in the amount of 12,000.00 which will be used as additional capital for her business.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional capital for her existing business

loans.name: Chourng

texts.en:
Chourng N., 24, is married and resides with her husband and child in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorian temples. She raises pigs at home to sell for an income of about $1 per day. Her husband (pictured) operates his motorbike with a trailer attached to give transportation services to villagers, earning an income of $4 per day.  

N. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to replace the old one because this motorbike often needs repairs. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair the house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: Buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Ailyn

texts.en:
Ailyn M. is a hog raiser and is also engaged in farming. She is 43 years of age and a native of South Cotabato.

Ailyn joined CEVI to finance the business she owns. She loaned the amount of Php 12,000 which will be used to buy farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Musharraf

texts.en:
Musharraf J. is a 48 year old woman. She is married with 4 children. Since Musharraf has lived with her husband, she has worked in the business of buying and selling cattle and also breeding sheep. She walks through the farms and several settlements to buy cattle at the lowest price to be able to increase her profits. Musharraf currently has 5 cows which she will fatten for some time to later sell them. With the loan she wants to buy additional young cattle and feed for the animals. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists, and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase young cattle and feed for them.

loans.name: Georester

texts.en:
Georester P. is from the village of Salimpuno, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old. Georester is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Georester owns & operates a business selling daily use products such as candies, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Georester has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Georester joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Georester has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used as additional capital for her business. Georester is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Georester from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Sem

texts.en: Sem R., 45, lives in Kompong Tom Province where she has had a medium-sized plot of farmland since she was single. She grows rice and has two crops per year, in both the dry and rainy seasons. To find additional income, she built a pigpen behind her house where she raises hogs and sells them when they mature. Sem R. is married and has four teenage kids. Two of them are no longer in school and work. Her husband, Ro, 44, distills rice wine to earn a living. Also, he makes natural medicine and sells it to patients who live nearby his village. Sem R. is taking out her loan to accumulate more pigs for her stall. Any remaining cash from the loan, she will buy raw materials for her husband use to produce medicine.

loans.use: To obtain more pigs for her stall.

loans.name: Francoise

texts.en:
Francoise is 36 years old and is married with four children. She works hard for the purpose of growing her business and taking care of her family.

Francoise has chosen this general store business in her place of residence that you see in the photo because it is profitable. Her business is well organized and she employs three people as helpers so that her business runs smoothly. The hours of her business are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening except on Sunday.

Francoise is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her business through purchasing more products for her shop. Once her vision is reached, she will be able to attract more customers which will allow her to earn more profits.

loans.use: To expand her business through purchasing more products

loans.name: Mrs. Koeun Chea Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of fifteen people located in Chong Kaoh-I village, Kandal province. They have selected Mrs. Koeun C. as the village bank president. The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways.

Mrs. Koeun C., who is 45 years old,  is a congee (a type of rice porridge) seller in the local village while her husband, Mr. Him S., is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows crops to sell to support his family.

But now, Mrs. Koeun C. has some problems because her husband’s field is infertile and it has a lot of insects. So, to improve production, she is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer and pesticide.

Mrs. Koeun C. is the mother of two children, one of whom is helping his father to farm, while the other is attending the local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticide for her husband's farm

loans.name: María Esther

texts.es:
María Esther es una madre de familia de 37 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y a su hijo en el sector El Sandial, una centro poblado rural del distrito de Pítipo, un distrito agrícola de la provincia de Ferreñafe, se encuentra ubicado a hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a la crianza de animales menores desde hace cuatro años en su domicilio, cuando estos ya han alcanzado un buen nivel de desarrollo los ofrece en venta a sus vecinos y a los negociantes que siempre visitan el lugar en done vive. Ella alimenta a sus animales con alimento concentrado y forraje, el cual sembrado por su esposo de este modo garantizan el rapido crecimiento de sus animales, lo que les permite comercializarlos de mejor manera y percibir mayores ganancias.

María Esther desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de ovejas con las cuales piensa trabajar del mismo modo: engordándolas y vendiéndolas en la misma zona, para lograr su objetivo se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a EdpymeAlternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles.

Con el préstamo ella podrá ampliar su negocio y nivel de ventas, asimismo la calidad de vida de su familia mejorará. María Esther es una mujer entregada a su familia y estimada por sus vecinos y conocidos.
texts.en:
María Esther is a 37-year-old mother that lives with her husband and son in the Sandial sector, a rural population center of the district of Pítipo, which is an agricultural district of the province of Ferreñafe, located an hour and a half from the city of Chiclayo. María Esther has been dedicated to breeding smaller animals for four years in her residence. When they have reached a good level of development she offers them for sale to her neighbors and to the businessmen that always visit the place where she lives. She feeds her animals with concentrated food and fodder, which is sown by her husband. In this way they guarantee the rapid growth of her animals, which permits them to market the animals in a better way and to receive greater profits. María Esther desires to expand her business with the purchase of sheep which she plans to work in the same way: fattening and selling them in the same zone. To achieve her objective she has been seen the need for the first time to request a credit of 500 new soles from EdpymeAlternativa . With the loan she will be able to expand her business and her level of sales, and likewise improve the quality of life of her family. María Esther is a woman devoted to her family and well regarded by her neighbors and acquaintances.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy sheep to fatten and sell

loans.name: Silvia

texts.en:
Silvia J. is currently in the business of selling first-class clothes, bedsheets and women's headdresses at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock shoes and saddles to sell.  

Silvia is 43 years old and married to a chief. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to expand her business by opening a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock shoes and saddles to sell

loans.name: Horng

texts.en:
Horng M., 62, is a widowed farmer who lives with her four children in the Takeo province. She typically makes $1.00 U.S. each day, and she would like to increase her profits. 
Horng M. receives additional support from three of her children: two are garment factory workers and one is a hairdresser. Horng M. is requesting a loan of $1,000.00 United States dollars to purchase hairdressing tools for her daughter.

loans.use: To purchase hairdressing tools for her daughter.

loans.name: Wendy

texts.en: Wendy G. is a married woman who lives in Barangay Palanas, Ginatilan, Cebu. She earns her living by operating three business ventures: fish vending, hog raising and farming. Her husband, Pepito G., who is 45 years old, works as a fisherman and carpenter to earn his living. They have five children who are from 10 to 25 years old. Wendy joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2005 because she wished for something better for her family. With the help of her past four loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, she has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 14,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 6,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living. This time, for her 5th loan, Wendy is borrowing PHP 16,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for her business so that she can continue to save for the future college education of her children. Wendy is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue in its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by visiting the NWTF lending team on Kiva to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Nuch

texts.en:
Nuch S., 44, is widowed and resides in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. She sells vegetables for an average income of around $4.10 per day. Every month the family has to spend $50 on food, $1 on electricity and $2 on transportation every month.  

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more vegetables to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to resell

loans.name: Thekrayat

texts.en:
Thekrayat is a young woman from Jenin city. Her father and one of her brothers are Palestinian National authority employees.

Thekrayat is a university student and works in a women's wear store.
